unnormalised: ## My Aadhaar Adventure: A Comedy of Errors (and Numbers!)
normalised: ## My Aadhaar Adventure: A Comedy of Errors (and Numbers!)

unnormalised: Okay, folks, buckle up. This isn’t your average "how to apply for Aadhaar" guide. This is the story of *my* Aadhaar application. Let's just say, it's been a journey. A journey filled with more bureaucratic hurdles than a Commonwealth Games steeplechase event.
normalised: Okay, folks, buckle up. This isn’t your average "how to apply for Aadhaar" guide. This is the story of *my* Aadhaar application. Let's just say, it's been a journey. A journey filled with more bureaucratic hurdles than a Commonwealth Games steeplechase event.

unnormalised: It all started innocently enough. I needed an Aadhaar card. Seemed simple, right? “Just a number,” they said. “Easy peasy,” they said. Little did they know, they were unleashing me, a walking disaster area, onto the unsuspecting world of government forms.
normalised: It all started innocently enough. I needed an Aadhaar card. Seemed simple, right? “Just a number,” they said. “Easy peasy,” they said. Little did they know, they were unleashing me, a walking disaster area, onto the unsuspecting world of government forms.

unnormalised: First, the documentation. Finding the right "proof of address" was an adventure in itself. My electricity bill was rejected because the meter number wasn’t printed clearly enough. Apparently, the machine thought my meter no. was "M378OL" instead of "M3780L". Seriously? Close enough! Then, my passport photocopy was deemed "illegible" because...well, I honestly don’t know why. The photo clearly showed my perpetually bewildered expression. Maybe they thought I was trying to smuggle in a miniature poodle under my hat?
normalised: First, the documentation. Finding the right "proof of address" was an adventure in itself. My electricity bill was rejected because the meter number wasn’t printed clearly enough. Apparently, the machine thought my meter number was "M three seven eight O-L" instead of "M three seven eight zero L". Seriously? Close enough! Then, my passport photocopy was deemed "illegible" because...well, I honestly don’t know why. The photo clearly showed my perpetually bewildered expression. Maybe they thought I was trying to smuggle in a miniature poodle under my hat?

unnormalised: Then came the application form. Let's just say, filling out the fields was like trying to solve a Rubik's Cube blindfolded. The instructions were about as clear as mud. I swear, half the questions were written in some ancient Sanskrit dialect. “Enter your father's maiden name’s paternal grandfather’s village panchayat code.” Dude, seriously? I barely know what I ate for breakfast.

I barely know what I ate for breakfast.

unnormalised: And the biometrics! Oh, the biometrics. My fingerprints were apparently too "worn down" for the scanner. This, I blame on years of aggressively stirring chai. The operator suggested I try moisturizing. I considered blaming my career as a professional thumb wrestler. He also struggled with my iris scan. "Please look directly into the camera," he said. I did. Apparently, my soul is too confusing for the machine to handle.

unnormalised: Finally, after what felt like an eternity, I received my Aadhaar number. The glorious, 12-digit sequence that would unlock the doors to a brave new world of government services. My number? **2468 1357 9012**. (Don't worry, that's a fake. I value my privacy, even after this whole ordeal.)

unnormalised: Armed with my precious number, I tried to link it to my bank account. Another comedy of errors. Apparently, there was a "mismatch" in my name. According to the bank, I was “Aniket Sharma”. According to my Aadhaar, I was “Aniketh Sarma”. A single rogue ‘h’ caused the digital equivalent of World War III.

unnormalised: So, here I am, still battling the bureaucratic beast, one form at a time. My advice? Approach the Aadhaar application process with a sense of humor. Because if you don’t laugh, you’ll cry. And potentially develop premature grey hair.
